title: Understanding China
description: The history of China is both rich and complex, as is its development in the modern era. The growing influence of China on the world stage, as one of the largest economies, a prominent player in international relations, and a major centre for knowledge creation, highlights the need for an integrated and multi-disciplinary understanding of its past and present. This course brings together several perspectives on China in addressing the following topics: cultural and intellectual roots, epochal events in history, modernisation and social change, economic development, and science and technology. This online course is required of all undergraduates admitted in 2022-23 and thereafter.
outcome: Students enrolled in this course will (1)      acquire a basic understanding of selected key cultural concepts that have shaped individuals and society in Chinese history, with reference to the Confucian, Daoist and Buddhist traditions;(2)      gain an appreciation of the complex forces that have impacted historical development in China and contributed to unity and division, the cultural and ethnic diversity of the nation, as well as continuities between past and present in government institutions, in the relations between China and the West, and in the historical-mindedness of the people;(3)      develop a basic grasp of the modernisation of China as a movement of national salvation and self-empowerment involving giant social transformations, the emergent role and influence of China as an important member of the international community, and the concept of modernity in relation to Westernisation and globalisation;(4)      become familiar with selected milestones in the economic development of China in the last two centuries, in particular the period since the founding of the People’s Republic, and future challenges in sustainable development;(5)     acquire a basic knowledge of the major scientific and technological advances in ancient and modern China, with an understanding of the significance of these achievements as well as their limitations from a comparative cultural perspective in the study of scientific discoveries;(6)      develop an understanding of the phenomenon of China rising in the broader context of Chinese culture and history, and reflect on how one may respond to the challenges of China;(7)      enhance awareness of cultural differences, leading to further reflections of one’s own cultural identity;(8)      develop a deepened appreciation of the complexity, grandeur and richness of Chinese history and culture, and with it a potentially enhanced sense of national identity.
syllabus: I. IntroductionThe introductory lecture will articulate the objectives of this core requirement in the context of the history and mission of CUHK, as well as the challenges facing Hong Kong as a special administrative region of China and as a major international metropolis in an increasingly globalized world. It will outline the different themes and topics to be covered, and how they contribute to the overall structure of the course. II. Understanding China: Intellectual FoundationsCulture has significant transformative power on the individual and society. It informs identity and the collective imagination. It shapes beliefs and values. In the Chinese context, the influence of Confucian, Daoist and Buddhist traditions has been deep-rooted and pervasive, finding expression in every level of Chinese society and every level of Chinese life, in ethics and religion, laws and government, education and science, art and architecture and other aspects of material culture, and shaping the ways in which people relate to each other, and how they view the world. Selected core concepts which figure prominently in the Chinese intellectual and cultural tradition will be critically examined, including the concepts of order and harmony, the junzi-ideal person, ren or benevolence and empathetic concern, li or ritual and propriety, and dao or the way. These ideas provide an entry into a world of ideas that is not only critical to understanding China but also significant to global dialogue. III. History as Mirror: Looking at Today’s China from the PastThe purpose of this part of the course is not to rehearse the history of China, but to explore the recurrent themes and conceptual underpinnings that fuel and impact the remarkable phenomenon of China rising.  We will examine five themes: (a) The grand unification of the Qin dynasty, and the central government and the standardization measures it introduced; (b) The Silk Road, consisting of a network of commercial and cultural cities leading from the ancient capitals of China through India and Central Asia all the way to the Mediterranean Coast, revealing the many-faceted and multi-levelled relations between China and the West; (c) Tang Cosmopolitanism, representing a golden age of cultural development which embraced an open-door policy, with the Chinese capital serving as a major centre of art, literature, philosophy and religion in Asia; (d) The Confucian Civil Service Examination, a three-tiered examination system administered at the local, provincial and national levels, which served for centuries as a method of recruiting civil officials, and can be said to be a model of participatory equality and meritocracy; and (e) The century of humiliation, covering the period of intervention and subjugation of the Qing Dynasty and the Republic of China by Western Powers  and Japan, from the Opium War to the founding of the People’s Republic of China in 1949.  IV. China’s Road to Modernisation The multi-faceted process of modernisation and social change demands careful attention. The modernisation of China can be distinguished from that of the Western nations in its being a historical movement of national salvation and self-empowerment, and also as a historical struggle to become one of the multiple centres of the world from a position of the periphery. From the perspective of social change, the country’s modernisation involved giant transformations from an agricultural civilisation to an industrial one, from a monarchy to a republic, and from the study of Confucian classics to the study of science, in a leap from “tradition” to “modernity”. This part of the course will discuss the underlying patterns of Chinese modernisation in relation to selected historical events of late Qing and Republican China, as well as the reforms of the People’s Republic of China, addressing issues such as the relationship between modernisation and Westernisation, and the possibility of different forms of modernity in the context of globalisation. V. The Chinese Economy: Past, Present and FutureThis part of the course looks at the Chinese economy in the context of the global economy. It reviews the economic development of China from the late Qing period to the present day, comparing it to the economy of other nations and with a focus on the developments since the founding of the People’s Republic of China, as well as projections for the future. The review makes reference to a wide range of economic indicators, including Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth, employment, imports and exports, income distribution, national savings, and infrastructure investment, as well as development strategies such as the dual-circulation economic development strategy and the internationalisation of the Renminbi. The lecture will also examine indicators related to sustainable development such as literacy and educational attainments, public health, prevention of climate change, air and water quality and the eradication of extreme poverty. VI. Science and Technology in China In the twenty-first century, science and technology are becoming an increasingly important facet of modernization for China, driving first an industrial and then an innovation economy, with major impacts on improving livelihood and in geopolitical competition. The topics covered in this part of the course include the Four Great Inventions, mathematics and astronomy in ancient and medieval China, and the question raised by Needham on why modern science emerged in Europe but not in China. Developments since the late Ming period are discussed with reference to science brought by missionaries, and the political, social and cultural reforms from the mid-19th century onwards. A critical examination will be provided of two recent periods, which saw achievements in a few centrally directed projects starting in the 1960s, and advances across a broad front since about 1980, but showing weaknesses in some sectors.

title: Hong Kong in the Wider Constitutional Order
description: This course views the overall development of Hong Kong from the perspectives of the nation and the wider constitutional order in China. It highlights the interlocking relations between law, national security and national development in the context of state capacity building in modern Chinese history, and introduces the fundamental constitutional principles underlying the One-Country-Two-Systems framework, the Basic Law of Hong Kong, and the Hong Kong National Security Law. This online course is required of all undergraduates admitted in 2022-23 and thereafter. It is recommended that students complete the online course UGCP1001 “Understanding China” before taking this course.
outcome: Students enrolled in this course will be able to: 1. Articulate the concept of “constitutional order” and the importance of understanding the position of Hong Kong in the wider constitutional order of China and the special administrative region; 2. Describe the dimensions of state capacity and its crucial role in the economic development of China; 3. Explain how the loss of Hong Kong in the wake of the Opium war is a symbol of state failure, as well as the historical roots of the rise of national insecurity from the mid-19th century onwards;  4. Describe the strategic objectives of China in adopting the One-Country-Two-Systems framework and the central tenets of the framework; 5. Describe the key features of the Hong Kong Basic Law and explain how it relates to the Constitution of the People’s Republic of China; 6. Identify types of insecurity in the contemporary world that are related to national security;​ 7. Describe the principles and key features of HKNSL; 8. Recognise a broader notion of HKNSL as an integral part of China’s constitutional system, which promotes multiple national developmental goals and pluralistic general principles for security and development in the region and the whole nation.
syllabus: IntroductionThe introduction will highlight the importance of understanding the constitutional foundation of Hong Kong within the larger context of China’s constitutional order. The educational rationale for the course will be articulated. The different themes and topics to be covered, and how they contribute to the overall structure of the course, will be outlined. Module I: Basic Concepts and ThemesThis module introduces several basic concepts and themes relevant to our understanding of the position of Hong Kong within the wider constitutional order of China. A brief historical perspective is provided on the influence of Chinese culture on the Chinese legal system, and the interlocking relationship between state capacity building, the Constitution of the People’s Republic of China, the One-Country-Two-Systems framework, and national security. Some issues pertaining to the intricate relationship between the National Constitution and the Hong Kong Basic Law are explored. The module ends with a note on the growing awareness in the world of security issues confronting all nations and societies, the importance of safeguarding national security, and the emergence of national security as a subfield of academic study. Module II: China’s Rise: a Bicentennial PerspectiveII-1.     State Capacity and Economic DevelopmentThe first lecture of Module II introduces the concept of “state capacity”, broadly understood as the ability of the state to turn its will into action and reality, in particular the building of infrastructural capacity. It is argued that state capacity provides the pivotal foundation for economic development, and played an important role in the development of early modern economies. The concept of “state capacity” helps explain the Great Divergence between the West and the rest of the world in the 18th and 19th centuries, and the difference in the developmental paths of Japan and China from the mid-19th century onwards. II-2.     The Decline of Old ChinaThe second lecture of Module II analyses the decline of China during the period from the time of the Opium War to the founding of the People’s Republic of China from the perspective of state capacity. It is argued that the decline of China during this period, or “Old China”, can be attributed to its weak and eroded infrastructural capacity, as reflected in its weak coercive capacity, extractive capacity and assimilative capacity. In terms of the state’s ability to maintain law and order, its Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita level, and its capacity to provide for education and public health, Old China ranked below most developing nations, and showed characteristics of what may be called a “failed state”.  II-3.     The Rise of New China and its Global ImplicationsThe third lecture of the module analyses the economic development of “New China” through a review of the unprecedented state capacity of the People’s Republic of China, as seen in the formulation, implementation, and execution of its nationwide policies. The successful transformation of China, the most populous nation which at one point ranked rock bottom in the world in terms of development, carries significant global implications which will be explored in the lecture. II-4.     “The March of the Volunteers”: The Birth of the National AnthemThe module concludes with a lecture that traces the socio-historical origins of “The March of the Volunteers” to a film, its composer, and the introduction of communal singing into China, as well as its reception in the West. Module III: One Country, Two Systems: Past and PresentIII-1.   The Constitution of New ChinaThe first lecture of Module III introduces us to some of the salient features of the Constitution of the People’s Republic of China. The general concept of a unitary state is introduced, referring to a system of central and local governments, with the latter deriving the rights of local autonomy from the authorization by the central government and having the obligation to preserve and defend the unity of the country.  The ancient Chinese constitutional wisdom in implementing “one country, many systems” under the rubric of a unitary state sheds light on the historical and constitutional foundation for both “one country” and “two systems”. III-2.  One Country, Two Systems: its Strategic Objectives and Core FeaturesCritical to our understanding of Hong Kong in the wider constitutional order is developing an in-depth and comprehensive understanding of the “One Country, Two Systems (OCTS)” policy.  The second lecture of Module III introduces the historical background for China’s policy toward the United Kingdom after establishing the People’s Republic in 1949, and in China’s negotiations with the British leading to the return of Hong Kong’s sovereignty to China. It also discusses the key tenets of OCTS from the perspective of current-day Hong Kong.   III-3.   The Constitution of PRC, The Basic Law of HKSAR and “One Country, Two Systems”The third and concluding lecture of the module focuses on the Hong Kong Basic Law, which is a national law of China. About one-fifth of the 160 articles of the Hong Kong Basic Law contain the term “the central government”. These articles substantiate the principle of “One Country” within the text of the HK Basic Law, highlighting the pivotal importance of these articles in maintaining the wider constitutional order. Module IV: National Security in the Wider Constitutional Order IV-1.       Dimensions of National Security The first component of Module IV covers two topics related to dimensions of national security.  IV-1A.    Financial Security: Financial Stability of Hong KongThe first topic focuses on financial stability. Factors that contribute to financial (in)stability are examined, making reference to the financial crises experienced in the 1980s and 1990s, as well as policies that will safeguard financial stability in Hong Kong.  IV-1B.     Information Security: The Bigger Picture-Do You Trust Your Big Data? The second topic addresses the issue of information security. The complexity of keeping data secure, guarding against misinformation and disinformation, and ensuring confidentiality, integrity and availability, is highlighted with reference to Big Data and Artificial Intelligence.  IV-2.   The Constitution and National SecurityThe second component of Module IV examines the relationship between national security and the Constitution. National security is an inherent aspect of the constitutional order, and it is a misconception to think of a national security law merely as a criminal law or an emergency law. IV-3.   Law as Safeguard: General Principles of HKNSL The third component of the module guides students in learning about The Law of the People’s Republic of China on Safeguarding National Security in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKNSL) by focusing on its general principles. The innermost essence of this law is about the central government’s overarching responsibility in safeguarding national security for all Chinese, country-wide and region-wide. HKNSL also safeguards the authority of the HKSAR government to lawfully guard national sovereignty, unity, territorial integrity, and other major national security interests in Hong Kong.   IV-4.   National Security Framework CasesThe fourth and final component of the module discusses some recent court cases pertaining to HKNSL and the constitutional significance of these cases.
